aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Incident Involving Cirrus SR22 in Gunnison, Colorado
The incident occurred in Gunnison, Colorado.
The incident occurred on February 14, 2014, at 14:23 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a CIRRUS DESIGN CORP SR22.
The defining event of the incident was structural icing.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The incident number was CEN14IA139.
The aircraft registration was N18DN.
The aircraft sustained minor damage.
There was 1 person on board with no injuries.
The pilot received a preflight weather briefing approximately 90 minutes before the flight.
The preflight weather briefing included an advisory for moderate icing between the freezing level and 22,000 ft mean sea level.
The freezing level was expected to be at or below 10,000 ft mean sea level.
The pilot reported encountering instrument meteorological conditions with light icing accumulation about 45 minutes into the flight.
The pilot advised an air traffic controller about the icing situation when the aircraft was operating at approximately 15,900 ft mean sea level.
Before the pilot decided on an alternate route of flight, the icing conditions worsened.
The aircraft was unable to maintain altitude due to the worsening icing conditions.
The air traffic controller noted this was the first icing report in that vicinity.
There had been earlier reports of light to moderate icing about 50 miles west of the aircraft's position.
The pilot was unsure of the height of the cloud bases in relation to the mountainous terrain below the aircraft's flightpath.
The pilot chose to deploy the parachute system due to uncertainty about terrain clearance.
The aircraft impacted a mountainside in approximately 10 ft of snow.
The mountainside impact occurred at an elevation of 11,000 ft mean sea level.
The pilot reported no pre-incident failures or malfunctions with the aircraft that would have precluded normal operation.
Available weather data indicated the freezing level was about 10,000 ft mean sea level at the time of the incident.
Available weather data indicated cloud tops were about 18,000 ft mean sea level around the incident site.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the incident to be the pilot's improper decision to initiate the flight into an area with forecast icing conditions.
The pilot's decision resulted in an encounter with in-flight icing conditions that prevented the aircraft from being able to maintain altitude.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Gunnison, Colorado

## Date & Time: 
February 14, 2014, 14:23 Local

## Aircraft:
CIRRUS DESIGN CORP SR22

## Defining Event:
Structural icing

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Incident Number:
CEN14IA139

## Registration:
N18DN

## Aircraft Damage:
Minor

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

About 90 minutes before the flight, the pilot received a preflight weather briefing, which included an advisory for moderate icing between the freezing level (expected to be at or below 10,000 ft mean sea level [msl]) and 22,000 ft msl. The pilot reported that the airplane encountered instrument meteorological conditions with light icing accumulation about 45 minutes into the flight. The pilot advised an air traffic controller of the situation when the airplane was operating about 15,900 ft msl; however, before he had decided on an alternate route of flight, the icing conditions worsened, and the airplane was unable to maintain altitude. The controller noted that this was the first icing report in that vicinity although there had been earlier reports of light to moderate icing about 50 miles west of the airplane's position. Unsure of the height of the cloud bases in relation to the mountainous terrain below the airplane's flightpath, the pilot chose to deploy the parachute system. The airplane impacted a mountainside in about 10 ft of snow at an elevation of 11,000 ft msl. The pilot reported no preincident failures or malfunctions with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation. Available weather data at the time of the accident indicated that the freezing level was about 10,000 ft msl with clouds tops about 18,000 ft msl around the incident site.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this incident to be:

The pilot's improper decision to initiate the flight into an area with forecast icing conditions, which resulted in an encounter with in-flight icing conditions that prevented the airplane from being able to maintain altitude.

---
